title: Will the Democratic Party nominate their presidential candidate on the first ballot of the presidential roll call at the 2020 Democratic National Convention?
preds: There´s no real controversy whatsoever about Biden. The democrats won´t be foolish enough to make it easier for Trump.
Always done that way - votes already in

(no change) If some of the D tribes are upset with VP pick (or just want a platform—I don't get out much ;-), there might be something related to either economic or racial justice. Wouldn't change the pick but might make some feel good.
No reason for sanders supporters to make life hard to Biddn.
DNC website only has info on Joe Biden. No one else is mentioned.  So going to 100pc
The entire party has gotten behind Biden as the nominee. Unless he is unable to perform the duties of the office, he will be nominated without issue this year.
Biden may die, then a brokered convention
There will probably be a virtual convention due to pandemic
I'm leaving open the possibility that Biden gets sick given his age.

For the Democratic Party to pull a brokered convention, there would have to be substantial fracturing; As bad as a candidate as Joe is for this election, they essentially have no other choice at this time, so I won’t say a brokered convention is impossible, only highly improbable and unlikely - this time.
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
Biden could contract covid-19 and pave the way for Bernie.
The Convention is now in August. Will the end date on this be extended?
Only very low probability events preventing it.
For the last >10 democratic conventions, there has only been one ballot. No reason to vary this down from that near 100% base rate.
Up 4% for passage of time & no impending drama.
No real opposition to a first ballot nomination.  Allowing <1% chance of Joe Biden being incapable of accepting the nomination, resulting in a brokered convention.
Since this question posted, much has happened re Biden.
Barring injury, illness or death of biden, he’s a shoe in
There isn't much choice for the Dems
There will be no waves at the convention this year.
Unless they decide to put on a show
They are trying to stop Bernie

Predictit: 95%
Crowd: 100%
Biden now less under scrutiny; convention is approaching

Just a PSA... Biden only needs 7.6% of remaining delegates to secure nomination. I'm presuming anyone with alternate forecasts are inactive forecasters in general: https://www.npr.org/2020/02/10/799979293/how-many-delegates-do-the-2020-presidential-democratic-candidates-have
Giving 2% of leeway just in case something happens to Biden.
Up 8% on this piece by Politico: https://www.politico.com/news/2020/05/15/tara-reade-left-trail-of-aggrieved-acquaintances-260771
Up 5%. With the expected convention format change, it would probably be easier to stage manage whatever the D's want to do.
Yes, unless Biden self-destructs, which is a possibility.

Joe Biden is the presumptive nominee with Bernie Sanders and other former competitors endorsing Biden.  Given Biden's age and having been treated for hyperlipidemia previously, I have slight concern about his health particularly given the COVID 19 epidemic where high cholesterol may be a risk factor for a poor health out should someone contract COVID19
The advent of Andrew Cuomo will change the number of votes at the convention from one to multiple as delegates are freed from commitments.

With recent poll sponsored by Republican leaning "Club for Growth" showing growing support for Gov. Cuomo and the prospect of having a virtual convention suggest we may be in for some surprises. Here is NY Post link to poll https://nypost.com/2020/04/10/democrats-want-to-drop-joe-biden-for-andrew-cuomo-poll-finds/
Biden is the "establishment" candidate and Bernie has now conceded. Historically losing candidates give over their delegate votes "by acclimation" and Sanders did this with Hillary in 2016.
Up 3% but August is a long time away.
Too late to plug up a better candidate than Uncle Joe, though they are out there (Inslee, Cuomo, ...)

If Biden does not win Ohio (unlikely) and Sanders remains emboldened then more than one ballot remains a possibility, albeit distant. One cannot rule out health issues at this point and if one or both of the front runners is sick the possibility of multiple voting  remains open.

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-52142638
Ds have moved their Big Meeting back to August.  That will presumably affect the closing date of this Q, but it probably won't change the result.
It would take much to topple Biden now
with Biden winning the latest primaries and the political process being consumed by the virus response, I would say the field has been set. Biden vs Trump with a lot of nasty campaigning now with us
Down 5%. July is a long time away and several possible grey swans come to mind.
Bernie's path to convention is very slim after super Tuesday - 2.
unless Biden dies, he will be the nominee
(no change) Might be a mail-in/call-in vote which may only loosely qualify.

The pandemic makes everything very unpredictable.  People will be torn over healthcare.  Candidates may get sick.  Trump may get sick or seriously mess up and no longer be Republican candidate.  All of this will change things and so likelihood of being decided quickly is lower than I would otherwise have said.
The desire to focus on beating Trump will bring great pressure to "get on with it".
Biden will go to Milwaukee with enough delegates to win on first ballot. He won’t need the super delegates.
Bernie will desist before the convention.

I am updating my forecast to reflect the fact that the Democratic primary has shifted significantly in favor of Joe Biden and it is all but certain he will handily secure the Democratic Party's nomination. This prediction change is a result of the domino effect of candidates dropping out and throwing their support behind Joe Biden rather than Bernie Sanders, as well as huge wins for Biden in the South that revived his campaign during Super Tuesday. The double digit margin in votes between Biden and Sanders that secured Biden's victory last night (March 17th, 2020) in the Arizona, Florida, and Illinois primaries seems but signal the end of any possibility  for Sanders to secure a national coalition of supporters. The remaining 2% of chance of the candidate not being chosen on the first ballot is accounting for a possible sudden failing in the eyes of Dem. voters for Biden to prove he is the only one who can defeat Trump ie. a health issue or major scandal.
Up 5% considering how things appear to be heading.
The days of the party convention deciding the candidate are long gone.
With Biden's sudden turn of fortune, it is unlikely that Sanders can catch up.

This may be the nation's first virtual convention, delegates will video in from the safety of their bedrooms. Delegates will want to get it over quickly so they can return to daytime TV. Or maybe they'll just vote using their phones, e.g. text the name to some random number. Either way it will be quick and painless.

(no change) It is to the DNC's benefit to continue to have BS rack up delegates. If something should make JB less desirable as the nominee before the convention, voting then dealing is an (awful, but available) option.
Up 45%. I now suspect GJO would close this question with a yes as long as they do not conduct a second vote. Thanks to the lengthy post by @Joseph-Noko below.

After this set of primaries, Biden has a clear path to a majority and Sanders' narrow path to nomination does not give him a majority of delegates as per: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/3-ways-the-next-2-weeks-could-go-even-the-best-case-scenario-for-sanders-doesnt-look-so-great/. Ceteris paribus, Biden just may deliver a clean and short primary if Sanders follows the math and gives up. I think the pragmatism of the electorate will land blow after blow against Sanders. The media calls it "the establishment", which is an odd way to describe a coalition driven by African-Americans, but anyway, "the establishment" is driven to beat Trump. Biden has loads of room to screw up, nobody will make a big deal out of it. People are woke to the reality that creating false equivalencies and drumming on about the weaknesses of their candidate opens the door for Trump. This sentiment will give Biden cover to win.

(no change) I see no reason to expect the trend this shows to significantly change: https://www.270towin.com/2020-democratic-delegate-calculator/ so I don't understand such a high consensus for a first vote nominee.

It appears to me that the information to decrease exposure to the covid-19 for older Americans includes avoiding crowds, will impact voting turnout in the final months of the primary. Therefore neither candidate will have the ability to pull away as a clear cut winner. Additionally, Sanders (demonstrating his Trumpism) will keep a court challenge viable to the process if he is not the candidate on first ballot. I project that the US spread of the virus will not wane until around June or July, if precautions are put in place quickly, which could suppress voter turnout all the way up to the convention.

Up 15% to be closer to the consensus. I need re-read (sigh) the DNC rules. —or at least think about them from a different perspective. There is what I would loosely call the "normal order" but I've been wondering if some motion from BS (for example) before the final first vote was tallied where it would just be settled without a second vote (bonus points for whether GJO would consider this course as on the first ballot since it would be something entirely different than a roll call decision.

The Biden support has increased dramatically and there is little reason to think the Sanders support will come back.  Everyone has cleared out to help Biden get the nomination.  There is really very little in his way.
It looks like Biden has it on first ballot but today will go along way toward indicating.

Sanders has promised to drop out and back Joe Biden if he gets the majority of votes/delegate (some language games can be played here) so there's no reason to assume that the fight will be taken all the way to a second ballot.
The field is down to two, with former Vice President Joe Biden in the driver
This race is not nearly as close as the last 2
They will probably go with whomever gets the nomination.
The field is down to two candidates and with only ~100 delegates given to candidates other than Bernie and Biden it is highly unlikely that neither of them gains a majority.
With only two candidates, the results should be clear from the beginning
Updating to incorporate Super Tuesday results

I may be overly optimistic and certainly Sanders can walk this back, but he has promised to stand down if Biden has a plurality of delegates even if he lacks a majority: https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/sanders-agrees-the-person-with-the-most-delegates-at-the-convention-wins-80035909591. I assume Biden would say the same. This commitment on Sanders' part raises the chances of a first ballot nomination. I think the pressure to unify and gear up to face Trump is huge this cycle and we will see a Democratic Party that will be ferociously ruthless in doing what it takes to win because Mission One for them is get rid of Trump and few will want the blame for helping Trump get over the line in November.
Up 20%. I don't understand the negatives of a 2nd vote, but perhaps I don't consume enough social media.

With the departures of Klobuchar, Buttigieg, and Bloomberg, only two viable candidates remain: Sanders & Biden. Warren's departure is inevitable. Whether Sanders or Biden wins is irrelevant. The only question is if the pledged votes for Warren, Bloomberg, Buttigieg, and Klobuchar will prevent a simple majority on the first ballot. As of today, 538 predicts Biden's odds to be roughly 30%. Sanders' odds are roughly 10%. Combined, that's 40%. However, I think enough moderate Democrats are concerned about Sanders' electability vs. Trump and will turn out in higher than predicted numbers to vote for Biden. Therefore, I think Biden will continue to surprise us in the upcoming primaries.
Super Tuesday results give Biden a shot at winning on the first ballot.
Biden's chances just dramatically improved following Super Tuesday.

In the past, the question was read as would Bernie be nominated on the first ballot.  Now that Super Tuesday is over, the question is will Biden be nominated on the first ballot.   I have not seen how the Super Tuesday delegates will be divided for each state.  However, it appears no one will have a majority.  Bernie will likely fight to the end--as he did in 2016, dooming Hilary.

softening and overcompensating backwards from previous 0% bet a couple days ago.  Pete and Amy dropping out shows that the majority are preparing to ensure no Bern as winner, but as Tom Friedman says, their chance is achieved if Bernie's beat "fair and square", hence win the balance of the campaign for a unified "centrist" pick. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/03/opinion/super-tuesday-democrats-unite.html?action=click&module=Opinion&pgtype=Homepagehttps://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/03/opinion/super-tuesday-democrats-unite.html?action=click&module=Opinion&pgtype=Homepage
The chances for this are increased now that Buttigieg & Klobuchar dropped out, possibly improving odds for Biden.  A brokered convention is looking more likely than before.

the electability of a candidate to seriously compete against Trump will push the "establishment" away from Sanders. The danger of a socialist ticket will affect the down ticket strategy. Still many chapters to be written before Milwaukie
Bernie can't be shaken from his tree. He can be knocked out with a super delegate stick.
Buttigieg's withdrawal now allows Biden or Bloomberg to begin consolidating the moderate vote. Sanders has not shown the ability to reach beyond his base.
I'm adjusting this down after Steyer and Buttigieg dropped out because it indicates the party may be influencing them to coalesce behind Biden.
Overexposed high.  Dropping lower due to Buttigieg dropping.  Hope to remember to update after SuperTues.
If it happens, Biden will be the nominee, not Bernie.

At this point, before Super Tuesday voting, I  see it as a toss up as to whether Biden will get a majority or whether it will be a brokered convention. A lot will depend on whether the center coalesces around Biden by Super Tuesday,  or if Bloomberg, Buttigieg and Klobuchar siphon off enough support to keep Biden from garnering a majority before the convention.
Contentious vision towards which values to take forward in governance and who would be best placed to bring them to fruition
No one candidate will win the majority of delegates
the high probability of a brokered convention
Biden's strong showing in SC presents him as alternative to Buttigieg for moderate vote.
Updating for big Biden win in SC

I'm betting simply that Bernie doesn't win the first ballot.  Dems know they can't win 2020 without winning the "middle" and there's enough debate that Bernie wouldn't win the middle such that he doesn't successfully "negotiate" in excess of 50% of delegates away from exiting candidates going into the convention.  Interestingly, in Canada party leadership conventions rarely win on the first ballot and usually run to even 3 or more ballots. They also have the resulting luxury of avoiding the years long newscycle feed and money laden campaigns of the state by state (province by province) "primaries".

The superdelegates will be in play against Sanders unless he manages to clinch the needed delegates in the primaries. His lack of support among African-Americans will allow Biden to get enough delegates to stop him
Looking at polling by 538 I see no clear winner by either majority or plurality.
Too many candidates will stay in the race until the convention such that no one will achieve the required delegate count and a contested convention will result.
Things will still very much undecided in July.

Expecting a winnowing of the field after Super Tuesday. Perhaps only 3 candidates left by the DNC (Bernie, Biden, Bloomberg, by my guess).  Yes, 538 sees no candidate obtaining a simple majority on the first ballot 52% of the time.  However, those forecasts will change materially if/when we see dropouts. Additionally, I think the DNC wouldn't let this happen, would be awful for the party. Will reassess after Super Tuesday, tail risks include Biden upsets, and any major candidate not hitting the required 15% to receive delegates.
too many candidates and the leader is a socialist. Should be total chaos.
Updating due to Biden surge today.
WIth Bloomberg and Steyer staying in, because of their money, I don't envision Bernie getting 51% of the delegates by the Convention.

I think it is pretty unlikely that Bernie (who is the only one with a chance right now) will not win a majority of the delegates pre-convention.  Also, I doubt Bernie will be able to change the rules so that he will win on the first ballot with a plurality.
I think that Democrats will tend to avoid any more chaos making them look incompetent.

looking a the
polls all the candidates have a mixed basis and territory

The only reason why I am so certain about this is the optics on the DNC if they do not. They have had a lot of scandal from the last presidential election and I think they do not want to ruffle any feathers. No, a large portion of Democrats do not support the current front runner but this is out of the DNC's control.
I doubt they will on the first ballot, especially if Bernie is the front runner. The bulk of the party are not fully behind Bernie.
Bernie has a good lead but Biden will pass him. The real decision will be determined by who drops out and how much time Bloomberg spends actually talking to voters. It will be a long process.
A stop Bernie campaign might still arise
I don't feel like the Democratic establishment is going to let Bernie win so easily, and I believe he'll have the majority of the delegates going into the convention.
It will be a choice between 3 candidates by end of the day on Super-Tuesday! And one of the candidates will turn out to be a spoiler tilting overall advantage to one of the candidates.

Reference: https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/02/04/contested-presidential-conventions-and-why-parties-try-to-avoid-them/ One possible external view on this question is that there have been 18 candidates not elected on the first ballot out of the last 60 presidential conventions (30 x 2 parties since 1868). So that would imply an external rate of approximately 30% (or a 70% answer to this question). The inside view as represented by 538 modeling says 42% (58%) and Predictit says 50% (50%).  I don't have a strong view except to say that I think odds of a Democratic convention in 2020 with a winner on the first ballot are likely to be lower than the long term average. So I'm going with about 50/50.
Result should be clear by then
I think the nomination will take two or more ballots.
Fivethirtyeight currently puts Sanders at 46% chance of winning a majority of pledged votes. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/?ex_cid=rrpromo
It's the speed you need to go to travel through time in a DeLorean. Also, at this time it appears as though Bernie will have more than enough delegate/primary support to win first ballot.

I think there is a greater likelihood that the DNC does not nominate on their first ballot. There are many aspects to consider. In 2016, Bernie had a lot of momentum behind him but arguably the institution of the DNC did not want him as the presidential nominee. That could be the case this time around and that even if Bernie does do relatively well in the caucuses and primaries, they could push for a brokered convention. Also, with many viable moderate candidates, Bernie's support will be tested as the election carries on. On the other hand, in 2020 new ideas and new movements may be necessary to beat Donald Trump and if Bernie runs away with delegates, the DNC would look like they are anti-democracy by invalidating his win. Finally, it would be bad politics to show that much disunity by voting more than once.
I'm pretty sure the last time it took more than one ballot was in 1952....

The democratic party must know how terrible the message would be if they have a contested convention. Assuming Bernie's early success continues (and there seems no reason it won't), he will either have a sufficiently strong plurality to need only a few votes from non-winning candidates' delegates, or an outright majority, on the first ballot.
A lot of runners in the contest means this would be difficult.

With Bernie Sanders taking a landslide victory in Nevada, it would appear that there is a clear possibility for him to continue gaining momentum and end up as the clear frontrunner. However, the fact that there are so many other candidates-- including Mayor Bloomberg who has not even been on a ballot yet-- in the running who are occupying so much space on the field that they are unwilling to give up means that it is unlikely for that to change before the June convention where candidates will have more of a chance to make a statement. This information is based off of FiveThirtyEight's predictions as well as Politico assessments of the field.
Right now it looks like Sanders is going to win the plurality of the delegates, at least.  I put a 50% now as a place holder.
Too many factions, too contentious, It is unlikely that consensus will be reached in one vote.
what does the base rate say?
The Super Delegates will participate in the second round in selecting the nominee.
Tricky one - the DNC does not want Bernie, while he will take all but a couple of states

What a situation the DNC has gotten into. Bernie has become a movement that is independent of the need for a leader. If the Est. overrides the Bernie Wave, DNC will in effect replicate the conditions in 2008 and 12 that gave birth to a Tea Party. the ying is about to get a yang, unless Bernie has a medical emergency when the weather warms up on the trail.
I feel that by the time the convention arrives, clarity will occur among the party. That said, there are too many potential candidates to be completely sure of this occurrence.
The divide between the far left and moderates in the party is growing.

Just about now in every quadrennium, the press start to predict a brokered convention for whichever party doesn't have a clear winner yet.  They have been relentlessly wrong about this for decades, but must keep it up because they are terrified of giving up athletic and horse-race metaphors for talk about ideas.  They suppose such a move would kneecap their ratings, and they are probably correct.    Nonetheless, both major parties have so far navigated through this awkward period with a definite result, although frequently not a happy one.  That's the most likely outcome this year as well.
Unlikely due based on what some candidates said February 20.

A brokered convention can occur if all the following are true:  a) No candidate wins a majority of the delegates
b) A candidate convinces another candidate to give them their delegates prior to the first round of voting and that gives them a majority. (I'm not entirely sure about this one). From an outside perspective, brokered conventions have never occurred in modern politics. The most recent brokered convention was in 1952.  The key to avoiding a brokered convention is candidates dropping out of the race; that frees up voters to switch to the leading candidates and allows the leading candidates to gain a majority of the delegates. My answer to this question is very contingent on candidates dropping out. I think that candidates haven't dropped out like normal for a variety of reasons (Iowa kerfuffle and the success of Klobuchar in NH). I think Nevada may bring some clarity and I anticipate candidates dropping out after Super Tuesday if it doesn't go their way. However, the longer candidates stick around the more likely they want to say because a brokered convention becomes more likely. So, I will be carefully monitoring candidates and whether they will drop out to answer this question. Right now I'm going with the outside view because of how little information we have on these candidates actual success in elections.
It does not seem likely based on current behavior by DNC and other party leaders

Initial forecast. Too splintered. I think it goes to the second round before the (old name) Super Delegates get to vote and suspect it will. The rules for releasing pledged delegates are complicated but details here: https://ballotpedia.org/Democratic_delegate_rules,_2020
